newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish Match H1 profit jumps 33 pct.
newsitem.headline: Swedish Match H1 profit jumps 33 pct.

text.p: Swedish tobacco and lighter company Swedish Match said on Tuesday its profit after financial items rose 33 percent in the first half of 1997, despite a decline in the cigarette market.
The group posted a profit of 758 million crowns ($94.6 million) compared to 572 million a year ago and sales of 3.63 billion crowns versus 3.58 billion in the first half 1996.
Analysts expected the company to post a profit of 799 million crowns for the period. The share traded up 0.20 crown at 24.40 after the result.

Swedish Match said increased sales and higher prices of its moist snuff products helped compensate for a decline in cigarette sales. This division reported a 25 percent increase in operating profit at 232 million crowns compared to 186 million withg sales of 505 million crowns against 422 million.

Sales of cigarettes, of which its Blend brand has about a third of the Swedish market and its Prince brand another third, fell 15 percent to 779 million crowns. Operating profit slumped 28 percent to 238 million crowns.
Some eight percent of this decline was because of hoarding ahead of a tobacco tax increase on January 1, 1997, the company said.

An agreement which took effect on May 1 under which Swedish Match manufactures its Prince brand but House of Prince AB markets them explained the other part of the fall as well as a general market decline for cigarettes, the company said.
Swedish Match distributes virtually all cigarettes on the Swedish market.
-- Abigail Schmelz, Stockholm newsroom +46-8-700-1003 ($ = 8.015 Swedish Crowns)
